question: If you have 5 biased coins with probabilities \( e_1 = 0.1 \), \( e_2 = 0.2 \), \( e_3 = 0.3 \), \( e_4 = 0.4 \), and \( e_5 = 0.5 \), what is the probability \( P_5 \) of getting exactly 5 heads using the recurrence relation provided in the text?
solution:
To find \( P_5 \), we will use the recurrence relation given in the text:

\[
P_N = P_{N-1} \left( \frac{1}{2} + e_N \right) + \left( 1 - P_{N-1} \right) \left( \frac{1}{2} - e_N \right)
\]

1. For \( N = 1 \):
   \[
   P_1 = \frac{1}{2} + e_1 = \frac{1}{2} + 0.1 = 0.6
   \]

2. For \( N = 2 \):
   \[
   P_2 = P_1 \left( \frac{1}{2} + e_2 \right) + \left( 1 - P_1 \right) \left( \frac{1}{2} - e_2 \right)
   \]
   \[
   P_2 = 0.6 \left( \frac{1}{2} + 0.2 \right) + (1 - 0.6) \left( \frac{1}{2} - 0.2 \right)
   \]
   \[
   P_2 = 0.6 \times 0.7 + 0.4 \times 0.3 = 0.42 + 0.12 = 0.54
   \]

3. For \( N = 3 \):
   \[
   P_3 = P_2 \left( \frac{1}{2} + e_3 \right) + \left( 1 - P_2 \right) \left( \frac{1}{2} - e_3 \right)
   \]
   \[
   P_3 = 0.54 \left( \frac{1}{2} + 0.3 \right) + (1 - 0.54) \left( \frac{1}{2} - 0.3 \right)
   \]
   \[
   P_3 = 0.54 \times 0.8 + 0.46 \times 0.2 = 0.432 + 0.092 = 0.524
   \]

4. For \( N = 4 \):
   \[
   P_4 = P_3 \left( \frac{1}{2} + e_4 \right) + \left( 1 - P_3 \right) \left( \frac{1}{2} - e_4 \right)
   \]
   \[
   P_4 = 0.524 \left( \frac{1}{2} + 0.4 \right) + (1 - 0.524) \left( \frac{1}{2} - 0.4 \right)
   \]
   \[
   P_4 = 0.524 \times 0.9 + 0.476 \times 0.1 = 0.4716 + 0.0476 = 0.5192
   \]

5. Finally, for \( N = 5 \):
   \[
   P_5 = P_4 \left( \frac{1}{2} + e_5 \right) + \left( 1 - P_4 \right) \left( \frac{1}{2} - e_5 \right)
   \]
   \[
   P_5 = 0.5192 \left( \frac{1}{2} + 0.5 \right) + (1 - 0.5192) \left( \frac{1}{2} - 0.5 \right)
   \]
   \[
   P_5 = 0.5192 \times 1 + 0.4808 \times (-0.5) = 0.5192 - 0.2404 = 0.2788
   \]

Thus, the probability \( P_5 \) of getting exactly 5 heads is:

\[
\boxed{0.2788}
\]
